Authors: Baric, Vedrana Bolic; Hemmingsson, Helena; Hellberg, Kristina; Kjellberg, Anette
Article Title: The Occupational Transition Process to Upper Secondary School, Further Education and/or Work in Sweden: As Described by Young Adults with Asperger Syndrome and Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder
Abstract: The aim was to describe the occupational transition process to upper secondary school, further education and/or work, and to discover what support influences the process from the perspectives of young adults with Asperger syndrome or attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder. This qualitative study was performed in Sweden and comprised interviews with 15 young adults recruited from community based day centres. Support influencing the process included: occupational transition preparation in compulsory school, practical work experience in a safe environment, and support beyond the workplace. The overall understanding shows that the occupational transition process was a longitudinal one starting as early as in middle school, and continuing until the young adults obtained and were able to remain in employment or further education.

llama-3.2-3b-instruct.reason: The study design is qualitative, which does not meet the inclusion criteria of meta-analyses, systematic reviews of controlled trials, RCTs (including cluster RCTs), or quasi-experimental studies with a control group.

qwen2.5-7b-instruct-1m.reason: The study design is qualitative (interviews) without a control group and does not meet the inclusion criteria for rigorous evaluation. The intervention focuses on occupational transition preparation rather than specific employment policies, and the population includes young adults with Asperger syndrome or ADHD but does not specifically reference people with mental health disorders.

phi-3-mini-4k-instruct.reason: The study focuses on young adults with Asperger syndrome or ADHD in Sweden and does not specifically address employment outcomes or interventions for people with mental health disorders in the general population.
